Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Does the legacy of long-term chronic climate change alter ecosystem responses to short-term climatic extremes?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Climate change may be manifested in the Midwestern United States as a combination of gradual warming and changes in rainfall along with increases in extreme weather events such as heat waves and droughts. Such gradual and extreme changes have typically been studied independently, however they are most likely to occur simultaneously, raising important questions about how they may interact. For example, will the nature of ecosystem responses to drought be affected by a gradual increase in temperature? This project will address this question by building on a long-term climate change study in a Kansas grassland, the Rainfall Manipulation Plots (RaMPs) experiment. The RaMPs experiment has imposed 15 years of altered rainfall patterns, larger rainfall events and longer periods between events, and 10 years of continuous (1-2 degree C) warming. Those treatments have resulted in consistently dry soils, increased plant water stress, reduced plant growth, genetic changes in populations of the most abundant grass species, and changes in soil carbon dioxide emissions, nutrients, and microbes. These varied responses are predicted to increase the ecosystem's resistance to extreme drought and its ability to recover after drought. To test those predictions, two years of extreme drought (similar to the 1930's dust bowl) followed by a year of normal rainfall will be imposed on experimental plots and multiple ecosystem responses will be measured.

A field-based course for undergraduates entitled 'Climate Change and Grasslands' will be offered. This course will enhance students' basic understanding of the scientific process and introduce them to the complexities of climate-ecosystem interactions through lectures, class projects and field trips that showcase results from climate change experiments in Wyoming, Colorado and New Mexico.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to assess how grassland ecosystems respond and potentially adjust to natural and experimentally altered climate variability. To do this, we added new treatments and new measurements to an on ongoing experiment, in which we had experimentally manipulated the timing and amounts of rainfall and temperature in native tallgrass prairie plots. During this previous 15 years, we established study plots covered with rainout shelters and irrigation systems that allowed us to alter the timing of rainfall to simulate larger rainfall events (storms) separated by longer dry periods, a prediction of many climate change models.  The effects of long-term exposure to experimentally altered climate included: 1) consistently drier soils and increased plant water stress, 2) reduced aboveground growth and carbon dioxide release from the soil, 3) changes in the genetic identities of the most abundant grass with an increase in individuals that appear to be more drought tolerant, and 5) changes belowground in soil nutrients, roots and microbes. We predicted that these changes would increase this ecosystem’s resistance to extreme drought and ability to recover after drought. To test this, we collected one additional growing season of pre-treatment data, using the same long-term treatments that had been in place for 15 years, and then we imposed two years of extreme drought in both the “altered” climate shelters and in “control” shelters followed by a recovery year of normal rainfall. Multiple ecosystem responses were measured to test the hypothesis that the legacy of long-term chronic climate change will impact ecosystem responses to short-term climate extremes.

The drought treatment significantly reduced ANPP and plant cover in all treatments, as expected. In the first drought year, we observed legacy effects of previous treatments on both ANPP and soil CO2 flux, but these legacy effects diminished in the second year of drought. As a result, the legacy effects of past climatic variability on recovery of ANPP and plant species cover and composition following two years of drought were minimal. These results suggest that the aboveground portion of these grassland communities are resilient to a moderately severe drought. In contrast to aboveground responses, we found soil CO2 flux to be more sensitive to the legacy of past treatments and to the imposed drought treatment, which is consistent with results from other experimental manipulations of drought in this grassland. Preliminary results for belowground plant responses to drought and post-drought recovery suggest that the legacy effects of treatment history and drought may be stronger belowground than aboveground, and we will continue to assess these response as we complete analysis of the data.  We also collaborated with a soil microbial ecologist to assess soil microbial responses to the long-term treatments and two-year experimental drought.  Data on soil microbial community responses are still being analyzed, and will be coupled with the belowground plant response data when completed. In addition to the project specific activities and results listed above, we made data, physical samples, and detailed information on infrastructure for precipitation manipulation experiments from this project available to other researchers.

We provided training and research experience for undergraduate and graduate students, and for professional research staff. Given that variability in precipitation patterns, mean temperatures, and the frequency and severity of drought are all forecast to increase in many regions of the globe, this research is broadly relevant to most natural and managed grassland ecosystems.
